ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Hiragana, Katakana, about 70 kanji, and several grammar structures. The class uses Tobira Level 1 and goes up to lesson 6.
I learned how to speak elementary Japanese and also learned basics about Japanese culture.
A great introduction to Japanese, Hiragana + Katakana + ~60 or so Kanji, simple phrases
I developed a strong foundation of the Japanese language that will definitely help me as I continue taking Japanese courses.
I learned L1 Japanese, which entailed basic conversation starters, and surface-level introductions. I learned about 500 vocab words, and enough grammar to understand basic conversations.
Japanese!
I learned Hiragana, Katakana, Kanji, and so many grammatical structures and vocab.
Learned basic japanese

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Japanese at Yale is highly engaging and fun. The professor was very attentive to student needs and very helpful. Every day you get to know your classmates well because we would pair up to practice the new content.
I think that even thought its a lot of work, meeting everyday and having nightly homework helped me learn faster. Talking with classmates also helped me improve faster.
Not a huge fan of assignments being in "Modules" rather than "Assignments"

The vocabulary and grammar was taught very well; the course was somewhat difficult, but that was necessary to effectively teach the language. I just wish there were less people per class so that I could get more individual time to speak, although I understand that's not a fault of the instructor.
I learned a lot a lot. Id say no weaknesses as long as the students know that theyre going into a fairly demanding course. Very great teaching style
No weaknesses. Clear instruction and engaging classroom environment.

Strengths: very straight forward teaching
Weakness: can sometimes move past harder topics to quickly

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
If you are interested in the Japanese language and culture I would suggest it. You learn a lot and at a pretty quick pace.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to anybody who want to learn Japanese.
Yes, it's a very good introduction to beginner learners for Japanese.
Yes! I learned a lot in just one semester and feel like I spent my time well. I also enjoyed learning parts of culture and Japanese.
Yes, but it does go fast. Be sure you can commit to this class before enrolling.
Yes
